entry.title: Error when binding list input in Approval Form (SAP Build Process Automation)
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I'm working on a process in SAP Build Process Automation where I have a user task ("Request Approval") that should display a list of items coming from the input data model.

In the "Inputs" tab of the Approval Form, I'm trying to bind a list to the form.

However, I encountered an issue, as shown in the screenshot below.

Is this a bug on SAP Build Process Automation side, or am I missing something in the configuration?

Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Best regards,

Giang Pham

entry.title: Error when I bind a list to the input of the Approval Form in SAP Build Process Automation.
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I'm working on a process in SAP Build Process Automation where I have a user task ("Request Approval") that should display a list of items coming from the input data model.

In the "Inputs" tab of the Approval Form, I'm trying to bind a list to the form.

However, I encountered an issue, as shown in the screenshot below.

Is this a bug on SAP Build Process Automation side, or am I missing something in the configuration?

Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Best regards,

Giang

entry.title: Request for Guidance on Notification Navigation in SAP Build Work Zone
entry.content:
Hello expert,

I have a process as shown in the picture.

I want the process to send a notification to Work Zone after I complete the approval step. When I click on that notification, it should navigate to the app I configured. 

And currently, I’m able to send a notification to Work Zone after the approval step is completed, as shown in the screenshot below

Now, I would like to implement the navigation behavior when clicking on the notification. Could you please guide me on how to achieve this? 

I sincerely appreciate your kind guidance and continued support. Thank you very much!

Best regards,

Giang

entry.title: Issue with ENOTFOUND Error in SAP Build Process Automation When Calling OData Service
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I'm currently working on SAP Build Process Automation and facing an issue while trying to consume an OData service in my workflow.

Destination configuration details in the sub account -

Proxy Type: OnPremise

Authentication: BasicAuthentication

Additional Properties: 

sap.applicationdevelopment.actions.enabled = true

sap.processautomation.enabled = true

sap.build.usage = odata_gen

sap-client = 200

WebIDEUsage = Mobile

HTML5.DynamicDestination = true

Content-Type = application/json

The OData service is already deployed in actions and accessible from SAP Build, 

but while testing the automation, I am getting the following error:

{
"type": "automationActivity",
"name": "irpa_core.log",
"label": "Get entities from btpStatus",
"inputs": [
"Action execution resulted in ENOTFOUND with message getaddrinfo ENOTFOUND sap2dev.ormat.com",
{
"key": "Error",
"value": 1
},
null,
true
],
"containerInstanceUid": "22088b84-5108-4cd6-9180-eb2744befb47",
"parentInstanceUid": "22088b84-5108-4cd6-9180-eb2744befb47",
"stepId": "4",
"line": 21,
"file": "statusUpdateOdata.js"
},

{
  "label": "getaddrinfo ENOTFOUND sap2dev.ormat.com",
  "parentInstanceUid": "00453074-c80a-b760-e576-a25a1f7d0e64",
  "containerInstanceUid": "5e569caa-b259-4fb8-b51a-176caadab2fb",
  "line": 2,
  "file": "bundle.js",
  "exception": "irpa_core.error.Error",
  "stack": "Error: getaddrinfo ENOTFOUND sap2dev.ormat.com     at Object.b [as cast] (C:\Users\saprpa\AppData\Local\SAP\Intelligent RPA\Projects\65287c4f-0b70-414b-a2f4-bccc626dca35\dist\bundle.js:2:204356)     at y.start (C:\Users\saprpa\AppData\Local\SAP\Intelligent RPA\Projects\65287c4f-0b70-414b-a2f4-bccc626dca35\dist\bundle.js:2:284311)     at async Object.p [as startJob] (C:\Users\saprpa\AppData\Local\SAP\Intelligent RPA\Projects\65287c4f-0b70-414b-a2f4-bccc626dca35\dist\bundle.js:2:278002)"
}

 

Can we use Proxy Type: OnPremise for OData services in SAP Build Process Automation, or is it recommended (or required) to use only Proxy Type: Internet (HTTP)?

I would appreciate clarification on whether OnPremise destinations are fully supported in SAP Build Process Automation workflows, especially when calling OData services inside automations.

 

Best Regards

Divan Wellalage

entry.content:
I want to convert my Form data into the Pdf or any other type of attachment .How to do that ?
SAP Build

entry.title: Build Workflow with SAP Build Process Automation: A Step-by-Step Demo on Invoice Validation Approval
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

In this blog, we’ll walk through the steps to create your very first process using SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA). We’ll implement an Vendor Invoice Validation and Approval Process, where a Finance Clerk submits a vendor invoice, and a Finance Manager approves or rejects it. You'll also learn how to set up your environment in a SAP BTP trial account, configure prerequisites, and monitor your workflow execution.

Understanding SAP Build Solutions

SAP Build is a comprehensive suite of low-code/no-code tools that empowers citizen developers and business users to create applications and automate processes without extensive coding knowledge. The SAP Build portfolio consists of three main components:

SAP Build Apps

  • Create and extend business applications
  • Drag-and-drop simplicity for app development
  • No coding skills required

SAP Build Process Automation

  • Create workflows and automate repetitive tasks
  • Unifies workflow management and intelligent robotic process automation
  • Streamlines business process management

SAP Build Work Zone

  • Create beautiful business websites and corporate portals
  • Centralized access to business applications and content

All these tools leverage drag-and-drop functionality, making them accessible to users without programming expertise.

Prerequisites

  • SAP BTP Trial Setup
  • Ensure that you have a SAP BTP trial account with the following services enabled:   
  • A. SAP Build Process Automation (Free Tier or Standard Plan)
    • Navigate to Service Marketplace > Search for SAP Build Process Automation
    • Click Create Application if it’s not already available.

                  

  • B. SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS)
    • Configure IAS (Identity Authentication Service).
    • Either use the default IAS tenant of your BTP trial or configure an additional tenant or default plan if needed.        

Subscribe to SAP Build Process Automation and Cloud Identity Service into your sub-account.         

  • Role Collection Assignment in BTP Cockpit
  • Assign the following role collections to the user you’ll log in with:                 

Go to BTP Cockpit > Security > Users

Select the IAS user and assign above role collection

  1. Establish Trust with IAS
  2. Go to BTP Subaccount > Security > Trust Configuration
  3. Add a new Identity Provider if you are using a custom IAS tenant
  4.  Enable trust for that IAS and assign the user created in IAS

Step 1: Accessing SAP Build Process Automation

  1. Navigate to your SAP BTP subaccount
  2. Go to Services → Instances and Subscriptions
  3. Open the SAP Build Process Automation application
  4. You'll be directed to the SAP Build Lobby - the central entry point for all SAP Build tools    

Step 2: Creating a Business Process Project

  1. In the SAP Build Lobby, click the Create button
  2. Select Build an Automated Process
  3. Choose Business Process
  4. Create a new project with these details:
    • Project Name: Invoice Validation Approval Process Form
    • Description: A invoice validation and approval process form project
  5. Click Create

The project acts as a container to hold the business process and all related artifacts.              

Step 3: Creating the Business Process

  1. Within the project, create a new business process:
    • Process Name: Invoice Validation Approval Process
    • Description: A invoice validation and approval process
  2. Click Create                  

The Process Builder will open with a vertical layout (an improvement from the previous horizontal layout) featuring a convenient side panel for better usability.

Hands-On Demo: Creating a Vendor Invoice Validation Approval Process

Let's dive into a practical example by creating a complete vendor invoice validation approval process. This demo will involve three key personas.

Business Personas Involved:

  1. Business Expert/Citizen Developer: Creates and designs the business process
  2. Finance Clerk: Uses the vendor invoice order from to initiate the process
  3. Finance Manager: Reviews and approves.rejects vendor invoice orders.

                    

Step 4: Creating the Vendor Invoice Submission Form (Trigger)

  1. Click Add a Trigger
  2. Select Submit Form (one of three trigger methods: Form, API, or Event)
  3. Click Blank Form
  4. Configure the form:
    • Form Name: Vendor Invoice Submission Form
    • Description: Form to collect vendor invoice order
  5. Click Create               

Step 5: Designing the Vendor Invoice Approval Form

  1. Click Open Editor to access the form designer
  2. Add form elements using drag-and-drop:
    • Heading: "Vendor Invoice Approval Forms"
    • Subheading: "Vendor Invoice Submission Form review by Finance Manager"
  3. Add required fields:
    • Vendor Name (Text field)
    • Invoice Number (Number field, required)
    • Invoice Date (Date field, required)
    • Vendor Email (Text field, required)
    • Invoice Amount (Number field, required)
    • Due Date (Date field, required)
  4. Mark fields as required where necessary
  5. Save the form       

Step 6: Creating the Approval Form

  1. Click Add Process Step (plus icon)
  2. Choose Approval
  3. Click Blank Approval
  4. Configure the approval form:
    • Name: Vendor Invoice Approval
    • Description: Vendor Invoice order form for review
  5. Click Create

Step 7: Designing the Approval Form

  1. Click the three dots and select Open Editor
  2. Design the form with:
    • Heading: "Sales Order Form for Review"
    • Subheading: "Sales order form for review by sales manager"
  3. Add the same fields as the trigger form:
    • Vendor Name
    • Invoice Number
    • Invoice Date
    • Vendor Email
    • Invoice Amount
    • Due Date
  4. Set all fields to Read Only (since this is for review)
  5. Add additional text field for manager comments
  6. Save the form

Step 8: Configuring the Approval Form

  1. Configure the approval settings:
    • Subject: "A Vendor Invoice [Vendor Name] form is waiting for your "
    • Priority: High
    • Users: Process started by (for simplification)
  2. Map inputs from the trigger form output:
    • Vendor Name→ Vendor Name field
    • Due Date → Due Date field
    • Invoice Number → Invoice Number field
    • Vendor Email → Vendor Email field
    • Invoice Amount → Invoice Amount field
  3. Save the configuration                     

Step 9: Creating Notification Forms

Approval Confirmation Form:

  1. Click Add Process Step → Form → Blank Form
  2. Configure:
    • Name: Vendor Invoice Order Confirmed
    • Description: Form to handle confirmation
  3. Design with:
    • Heading: "Vendor Invoice form approved successfully. No further action required."
    • Subject: "Your Vendor invoice [Vendor Name] form is confirmed!"
    • User: Process started by
  4. Save the form              

Rejection Notification Form:

  1. Go to Project Overview
  2. Duplicate the Order Confirmed form
  3. Modify the message:
    • Heading: "Invoice rejected. Please review remarks and resubmit after corrections."
    • Subject: "Your Vendor invoice [Vendor Name] has been rejected                   

Step 10: Connecting the Process Flow

  1. Connect the rejection notification to the "Rejected" path of the approval form
  2. Connect the approval confirmation to the "Approved" path
  3. Ensure both paths lead to the process end                      

Step 11: Understanding the Release Process

Why Release Before Deployment?

Before any business process can be executed by end users, it must go through two critical phases:

  1. Release: Creates a versioned snapshot of your project
  2. Deploy: Makes the released version available in runtime environment

Initiating the Release

  1. Locate the Release Button: In the top-right corner of your project interface
  2. Click Release: This opens the release configuration dialog

Release Versioning System

SAP Build Process Automation uses semantic versioning with three components:

  • Major Version (X.0.0): Significant changes, incompatible with previous versions
  • Minor Version (1.X.0): New features, backward compatible

First Release

For a newly created project, you'll see the default version 1.0.0. Add a meaningful release note such as "First release" and proceed.

Patch Changes (1.0.X)

  • Minor text modifications
  • Small UI adjustments
  • Bug fixes

Minor Changes (1.X.0)

  • New features added
  • Workflow enhancements
  • Backward-compatible improvements                       

Step 12: Deployment Process

Accessing Deployment Options

Once your project is released, the Deploy button becomes available. The deployment process involves:

  1. Click Deploy: Opens the deployment configuration
  2. Select Environment: Choose your target runtime environment

Understanding Environments

Public Environment

  • Accessible by all users in the subaccount
  • Suitable for organization-wide processes
  • Default choice for most scenarios

Deployment Execution

Select "Public" as your environment and click Deploy. You'll notice the project status changes from "Released" to "Deployed" and becomes "Active."       

Step 13: Process Execution and Testing

Accessing the Deployed Process

Once deployed, your process becomes executable through multiple channels:

  1. Direct Form Link: Browser-accessible URL
  2. SAP Build Work Zone Integration: Embedded as tiles
  3. SAP Launchpad Service: Integrated into portal environment         

Testing Scenario: Invoice Validation Approval Process Form

Phase 1: Finance Clerk Representative Role

Navigate to the deployed process and access the form link. As a finance clerk, fill out the order form:

Sample Data:

  • Vendor Name: ABCD Company
  • Invoice Number: 1234
  • Invoice Amount: $1,000
  • Due Date: 2 days from current date
  • Vendor Email : test@gmail.com
  • Invoice Date : 01/08/2025

Submit the form to initiate the workflow process.                           

Phase 2: Finance Manager Approval

  1. Access Inbox: Navigate to SAP Build Lobby > My Inbox
  2. Review Submission: Examine the submitted order details
  3. Make Decision: Choose to approve or reject based on business criteria

In our example:

  • Vendor Name: ABCD Company
  • Invoice Number: 1234
  • Invoice Amount: $1,000
  • Due Date: 2 days from current date
  • Vendor Email : test@gmail.com
  • Invoice Date : 01/08/2025

Decision: Approved with comment "This order can be fulfilled"      

Phase 3: Confirmation Process

After manager approval:

  1. Automatic Notification: System sends confirmation to finance representative
  2. Representative Action: Acknowledges receipt of approval
  3. Process Completion: Workflow concludes successfully

                        

Step 14: Process Monitoring and Analytics

Accessing Monitoring Tools

Process administrators can monitor workflow performance through: Path: SAP Build Lobby > Monitoring > Process and Workflow Instances

Key Monitoring Features

Process Instance Overview

  • Start time and initiator
  • Current status (Running, Completed, Failed)
  • Environment and version information
  • Instance ID for tracking

                     

Conclusion

SAP Build Process Automation is transforming the way organizations approach workflow digitisation by placing powerful automation tools directly in the hands of business users. As Demonstrated in our Invoice Validation Approval Process scenario, even non-technical users - like functional consultants or business experts - can quickly build, configure and deploy intelligent workflow using drag-and-drop interfaces, without writing code.  

From creating triggers  forms and configure approval steps to sending dynamic notifications, SBPA provides all the essential building blocks to automate repetitive tasks and improve collaboration across roles. Its tight integration within the SAP BTP and its ectensibility with tools like SAP Build Apps make it to go-to solutions.

By empowering citizen developer, SBPA not only reduces IT backlogs but also fosters a culture of innovations and continous improvement across teams. Now is the time to explore your business landscape, identify time-consuming manual process and turn them into streamlined intelligent workflows that deliver  measurable business value.

entry.title: Automation project cannot run with desktop agent
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I was creating an automation project in build process automation according to docu:

process-automation-enablement/Workshops/Workshop A - short/1 The Basics at main · SAP-samples/process-automation-enablement · GitHub 

Everything worked for me. When triggering the automation manually the Desktop agent runs the automation. When releasing the projekt and submitting my form, the automation gets stuck in this state and doesnt trigger the Agent to run in.

There is no error msg. Just stuck in this state for a day now

In my environment i registered my agent and added a custom attribute

Attribute is also added to my Project.

 

The Agent is installed on my local computer and has latest version. its in Unattended Mode, so it should register new projects.

This is my process:

this is the automation:

Greetings

Rouven

entry.title: SAP Build Process Automation: Process Triggers: A Step-by-Step Demo on Invoice Validation Approval
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

Welcome back to our SAP Build Process Automation series! In this second blog, we'll dive deep into one of the most crucial aspects of process automation: how to trigger your business processes. Understanding the various trigger mechanisms is essential for building robust, automated workflows that can respond to different business scenarios.

Every business process follows a simple flow: it starts with a trigger, executes a series of activities, and ends with a desired outcome. The question is: how do we initiate these processes effectively? Today, we'll explore the four primary ways to trigger processes in SAP Build Process Automation with complete step-by-step instructions.

API Triggers

Let's walk through a comprehensive implementation of API triggers using our Sales Order Management example.

Prerequisites

Before starting, ensure you have:

  1. Access to SAP Build Process Automation
  2. A working process (we'll use the vendor invoice validation approval process project from previous episodes)
  3. Any Rest Client software (web or desktop version)
  4. BTP Cockpit access for service key retrieval - trial cockpit

Step-by-Step Implementation 

Phase 1: Project Setup and Preparation 

Step 1: Create a Copy of Your Existing Project from previous blog

  1. Navigate to SAP Build Lobby
  2. Locate your existing project (e.g., "Invoice Validation Approval Process Form")
  3. Select the project by clicking on it
  4. Click "Save As" to create a copy
  5. Enter new project details: 
    1. Project Name: Invoice Validation Approval Process Trigger 
    2. Description: A invoice validation and approval process trigger
  6. Click "Save" to create the new project   

Step 2: Access and Prepare the Process

  1. Open the newly created project
  2. Navigate to the process section
  3. You should see:
    • Four forms
    • One process
    •  Existing form trigger (Invoice Validation Approval Process Form)

Phase 2: Removing Existing Process and Adding API Trigger

Step 3: Remove the Existing Form Process

  1. Click on the existing form process (Invoice Validation Approval Process Form)
  2. Click "Remove" to delete the form
  3. You'll now see a block asking "How do you want to start your process?"
  4. Click "Add a trigger"

Step 4: Explore Available Trigger Options You'll see four trigger options:

  1. Submit a form: Creates/uses existing forms
  2. API trigger: For external system integration
  3. Event trigger: For event-driven processes
  4. Schedule trigger: For time-based execution

Step 5: Create the API Trigger

  1. Click on "API Trigger"
  2. Save the process (mandatory before creating API trigger)
    • Click the Save button
  3. Configure API Trigger Details: 
    • Name: Invoice Validation Approval Process Trigger 
    • Identifier: [Auto-generated - do not modify]
  4. Click "Create"
  5. You'll see a success message: "API trigger created successfully"   

Phase 3: Understanding API Trigger Configuration 

Step 6: Examine API Trigger Properties

  1. Click on the API trigger you just created
  2. Review Output Fields:
  • These are automatically synchronized from process inputs
  • Fields include: Vendor Name, Invoice Number, Invoice Date, Vendor Email, Invoice Amount, Due Date
  • These represent the data structure your API will receive

Step 7: Check Process Variables Synchronization

  1. Click anywhere in the process canvas
  2. Navigate to Variables tab
  3. Select "Process Inputs"
  4. Verify synchronization:
    • API trigger outputs = Process inputs
    • This ensures seamless data flow

Step 8: Review API Configuration Details

  1. Click on the API trigger
  2. Go to "Configuration" tab
  3. Note the important details:
    • Field Identifiers: Use these in JSON (not display names)
    • Mandatory Fields: All fields shown are required
    • Data Types: Note numeric vs. string vs. date formats

Phase 4: Project Release and Deployment 

Step 9: Release the Project

  1. Save all changes
  2. Click "Release" button in the top toolbar
  3. Confirm the release when prompted
  4. Wait for successful release message

Step 10: Deploy the Project

  1. Click "Deploy" button (appears after release)
  2. Select target environment (typically "Public Environment")
  3. Confirm deployment
  4. Wait for deployment completion
  5. Note the deployment success message

Phase 5: Accessing Deployment Information 

Step 11: Navigate to Control Tower

  1. Go to SAP Build Lobby home
  2. Click on "Control Tower"
  3. Navigate to "Tenant Configuration"
  4. Click on "Environments"
  5. Select "Public Environment" (or your deployment target)

Step 12: Locate Your Deployed Project

  1. Find your project: "Vendor Invoice Validation Approval Process Triggers"
  2. Click on the project name
  3. Navigate to "Triggers" tab
  4. Locate: "Vendor Invoice Approval API Trigger"

Step 13: Get API Endpoint Information

  1. Click on "View Trigger"
  2. Copy the API URL - you'll need this for Rest Client
  3. Review the Payload Definition - this shows the exact JSON structure required

Example URL Structure:  https://[Tenant-URL] /workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances

Example Payload Structure JSON: 

{  
"definitionId": "[auto-generated-id]", 
"context": {  
"Vendor Name": "string",  
"invoiceNumber": "number",  
"invoiceDate": "date", 
"vendorEmail": "string", 
"invoiceAmount": "number",  
"dueDate": "date"  
} 
} 

Phase 6: BTP Service Key Configuration 

Step 14: Access BTP Cockpit

  1. Open BTP Cockpit in a new tab
  2. Navigate to your subaccount
  3. Go to "Instances and Subscriptions"
  4. Locate "SAP Build Process Automation"

Step 15: Retrieve Service Key Details

  1. Click on "SAP Build Process Automation" service
  2. Navigate to "Service Keys" tab
  3. Click on existing service key (or create one if none exists)
  4. Copy the following values: 
{  
"endpoints": {    
"api": "[API_ENDPOINT]"  
},  
"uaa": {    
"clientid ": "[CLIENT_ID]",    
"clientsecret": "[CLIENT_SECRET]",    
"url": "[TOKEN_URL]"  
} 
}

Phase 7: Rest Client Configuration and Testing 

Step 16: Configure OAuth 2.0 Authentication

  1. Go to "Authorization" tab
  2. Select "OAuth 2.0" from dropdown
  3. Configure OAuth settings:
    • Token Name: SAP Build Token (or any name)
    • Grant Type: Client Credentials
    • Access Token URL: [TOKEN_URL from service key]
    • Client ID: [CLIENT_ID from service key]
    • Client Secret: [CLIENT_SECRET from service key]

Step 17: Generate Access Token

  1. Click "Get New Access Token"
  2. Wait for token generation
  3. Click "Use Token" when generated
  4. Verify: You should see "Authentication complete" message

Step 18: Configure Request Body

  1. Go to "Body" tab
  2. Select "raw"
  3. Select "JSON" from dropdown
  4. Enter the payload: 
{
"definitionId": "[DEFINITION_ID_from_step_13]",
"context": {  
"vendorName": "ABCD",
"invoiceNumber": 1234,
"invoiceDate": "2025-08-05",
"vendorEmail": "abcd@test.com",
"invoiceAmount": 1000,
"dueDate": "2025-08-08" 
}
}

Step 19: Execute the API Call

  1. Click "Send"
  2. Expected Response:     
{
  "status": "201 Created",
  "message": "New resource was created successfully"
}

Phase 8: Process Monitoring and Verification 
Step 21: Monitor Process Instance

  1. Return to SAP Build Lobby
  2. Navigate to "Monitoring"
  3. Click "Process and Workflow Instances"
  4. Locate your new process instance:
    • Status: Running
    • Instance ID: [Auto-generated]
    • Started by: API Trigger

Step 22: Review Process Data

  1. Click on the process instance
  2. Review "Process Details":
    • Vendor Name: ABCD
    • Invoice Number: 1234
    • Invoice Amount: 1000
    • Vendor Email: abcd@test.com
    • Due Date: 2024-08-08

    3. Check process flow: Should be waiting for approval

Phase 9: Complete the Approval Workflow 

Step 23: Access Manager Inbox

  1. Navigate to "My Inbox" app
  2. Login as Finance Clerk
  3. Locate the approval task:
    • Title: Vendor Name [ABCD]
    • Status: Open
    • All order details visible

Step 24: Process the Approval

  1. Click on the task
  2. Review order details:
    • Vendor Name: ABCD
    • Invoice Amount: 1000
    • Invoice Email: abcd@test.com
    • Due Date: 2024-08-08
    • Invoice Number - 1234
    • Invoice Date - 2024-08-05
  3. Add approval comment:
  4. Click "Approve"
  5. Confirm: "Task has been processed successfully"

Step 25: Handle Vendor Invoice Representative Notification

  1. Switch to Finance Manager role
  2. Check "My Inbox"
  3. Locate notification: "Vendor Invoice form approved successfully"
  4. Click on notification
  5. Review confirmation details
  6. Click "Submit"

Step 26: Verify Process Completion

  1. Return to "Process and Workflow Instances"
  2. Refresh the page
  3. Check your process instance:
    • Status: Completed
    • All approval messages visible
    • Complete process flow executed  

Conclusion

In this blog, we walked through the complete lifecycle of implementing API triggers in SAP Build Process Automation using a real-world scenario of vendor invoice validation and approval. From project setup to deployment, from obtaining service keys to testing API calls with Rest Client, we demonstrated how API triggers enable seamless integration between external systems and your automated workflows.

This approach empowers businesses to respond programmatically to events, ensuring faster and more scalable process initiation. Whether you're integrating SAP Build with external applications, triggering approvals based on backend systems, or building custom UI workflows, API triggers provide the flexibility and control needed for robust automation.

entry.title: Create Your First AI-Powered App in SAP Build Code with Joule and Generative AI
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

Generative AI is revolutionizing the way developers create applications, and SAP is at the forefront of this change. With tools like SAP Build Code and Joule, developers can dramatically speed up the entire development lifecycle — from designing data models to building intuitive user interfaces — achieving in minutes what once took weeks. This fusion of AI-powered intelligence and SAP’s enterprise-grade capabilities empowers teams to innovate faster, reduce manual effort, and deliver high-quality applications that drive real business value.

Step 1. Introduction to SAP Build Code and Joule

What is SAP Build Code?

SAP Build Code is part of the SAP Build family, enabling pro-code developers to:

  • Build clean-core compliant extensions
  • Use SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP)
  • Leverage AI-assisted code generation via Joule
  • Integrate with both SAP and non-SAP systems

It’s deeply integrated into SAP BTP and offers:

  • A built-in development environment
  • Access to APIs and services
  • Security, CI/CD, and runtime tools
  • Fusion development — collaboration between professional developers and business experts

Why Clean Core Matters

A clean core keeps your SAP S/4HANA system as close to standard as possible, enabling:

  • Faster innovation adoption
  • Easier upgrades
  • Reduced total cost of ownership
  • Improved security and performance

SAP Build Code supports this by focusing on side-by-side extensions on SAP BTP.

Where Joule Fits In

Joule, SAP’s AI copilot, helps you:

  • Generate CDS data models from natural language prompts
  • Build services, sample data, and annotations automatically
  • Add business logic without manually writing all boilerplate code
  • Create UI elements through guided wizards

Step 2. Building the Employee Skill Tracker Application

The session’s mission was to build a Finance Application in minutes using:

  • SAP Build Code for development
  • CAP model for backend logic
  • Joule for AI-driven code and UI generation

With just a natural language prompt, Joule generated the entities (Employee, Skill, Project, and Certification), their attributes, and associations. The CAP service layer and Fiori UI annotations were created automatically, enabling the team to jump straight into implementing business rules such as certification expiry alerts and skill-gap detection.

Application Overview

The application allows:

  • Creating employees, skills, projects, and certifications
  • Assigning skills to employees and tracking their proficiency levels
  • Allocating employees to projects and monitoring their start/end dates and status
  • Recording employee certifications with issuer details and expiry tracking
  • Automating business rules, such as flagging upcoming certification expiries or identifying employees with required skills for open projects

Step 3. Setting Up SAP Build Code

You can set up SAP Build Code in two main ways:

  1. Set-up the SAP Build and Business Studio using Service MarketPlace
  2. Booster in SAP BTP Cockpit – Works for trial and enterprise accounts.

For this session, the trial account + booster method was used:

Created a dedicated SAP BTP subaccount with SAP Build Code and Business Application Studio (BAS).
All required roles, entitlements, and services—including CAP runtime, SAP HANA Cloud, and AI-powered Joule integration—were enabled automatically, ensuring a ready-to-develop environment without any manual setup overhead.

Step 4. Creating the Full-Stack Application

Flow 1: Starting a Project

  • In the SAP Build Lobby, select Create → Application → Full Stack Application

  • Name the project, link it to a BAS Dev Space, and open it in Business Application Studio

Initially, the Employee Skill Tracker project was a blank canvas — no entities, no business logic, and no UI. Within minutes, Joule transformed it into a fully structured CAP application, complete with data models, OData services, and Fiori-ready annotations.

Flow 2: Generating the Data Model with Joule

Using a natural language prompt, Joule generated:

Entities:

  1. Employee (Name, Email, Department, Hire Date)
  2. Skill (Skill Name, Proficiency Level)
  3. Project (Project Name, Start Date, End Date, Status)
  4. Certification (Certificate Name, Issuer, Expiry Date)

Result:

  1. schema.cds for entity definitions
  2. service.cds exposing OData services for Employee management
  3. Fiori annotations for displaying employee skill matrices in a table

Example prompt snippet:

"Create a CAP data model for an "Employee Skill Tracker" application.

Entities:

  1. Employee — Fields: Name (String), Email (String), Department (String), Hire Date (Date).
  2. Skill — Fields: Skill Name (String), Proficiency Level (String).
  3. Project — Fields: Project Name (String), Start Date (Date), End Date (Date), Status (String).
  4. Certification — Fields: Certificate Name (String), Issuer (String), Expiry Date (Date).

Requirements:

  1. Use UUID as the key for all entities.
  2. Create associations so that Skills, Projects, and Certifications link to an Employee.
  3. Generate schema.cds with entity definitions and associations.
  4. Generate service.cds exposing OData services for all entities.
  5. Add Fiori UI annotations for each entity to support List Reports and Object Pages.
  6. Use titles for fields in annotations to make the UI user-friendly."

Result:

  • schema.cds with entity definitions
  • service.cds with OData service exposure
  • Fiori annotations for UI hints

Flow 3: Adding Sample Data

From the data editor:

  • Added mock data for each entity
  • Enhanced it via Joule prompt:

"Generate data/EmployeeSkillTracker.csv sample data for my CAP application with the following entities and relationships:

  1. Employee — Fields: UUID key, Name, Email, Department, Hire Date.
  2. Skill — Fields: UUID key, Skill Name, Proficiency Level, Association to Employee.
  3. Project — Fields: UUID key, Project Name, Start Date, End Date, Status, Association to Employee.
  4. Certification — Fields: UUID key, Certificate Name, Issuer, Expiry Date, Association to Employee.

Requirements:

  1. Create 5 employees with realistic names, emails, departments, and hire dates.
  2. Assign 2–3 skills per employee with varying proficiency levels (Beginner, Intermediate, Expert).
  3. Assign 1–2 projects per employee with realistic start/end dates and statuses (Planned, Active, Completed).
  4. Assign 1–2 certifications per employee with different issuers and expiry dates.
  5. Output data in CSV format compatible with CAP db/data folder.
  6. Ensure associations match using Employee UUID values."

Outcome: Meaningful, test-ready datasets.

Flow 4: Implementing Business Logic

With the core entities — Employee, Skill, Project, and Certification — in place, the next step was to add custom business logic that makes the Employee Skill Tracker truly useful.

Requirements:

  1. In the srv/employee-service.js, add the following rules:

  • Auto-assign “Onboarding” project to every new Employee when they are created, with Status = "Active" and Start Date = current date.
  • Prevent deletion of Employees if they have active projects. Show an error: "Cannot delete employee with active projects".
  • Validate Skill Proficiency Level so it must be one of: "Beginner", "Intermediate", "Expert". If not, reject with a meaningful message.
  • Auto-calculate Project Status: if the End Date is before today, set Status to "Completed".
  • Send a console log every time a new Certification is added for an Employee.

  1. Ensure logic uses CAP Node.js event handlers (before, after, on) appropriately.

  2. Output the complete srv/employee-service.js file with the implemented logic.

Joule wrote the JavaScript for these logic files directly from the prompt.

Once you click the Add button, the “Open Code Editor” option becomes visible. From here, you can leverage Joule to generate the required business logic automatically. With just a natural language prompt, Joule translates your intent into CAP service code — exactly like in the screenshot below — saving time on boilerplate and letting you focus on fine-tuning the rules.

Flow 5: Building the UI

With the backend logic ready, it was time to create an intuitive and connected user interface.

Using the SAP Build Code UI Wizard, we:

  • Generated a Fiori Elements List Report for the Employee entity to provide an at-a-glance view of all employees in the system.
  • Enabled navigation links from each employee record to their associated Skills, Projects, and Certifications, ensuring a seamless drill-down experience.
  • Configured key columns in the list report, including Department, Hire Date, and Total Skills, for quick decision-making.
  • Applied Fiori Annotations for better formatting — e.g., date pickers for Hire Date, semantic colors for project status, and quick badges for expiring certifications.

Step 5. Running the App

After dependencies installed:

  • Backend OData services and frontend UI were available instantly
  • UI showed customer list, purchases, and redemptions
  • Business logic executed when adding purchases or redemptions (reward points updated automatically)

Step 6. Key Takeaways

  • Speed: Built an Employee Skill Tracker app from scratch to a functional CAP + Fiori app in under 15 minutes using Joule-generated entities (Employee, Skill, Project, Certification).
  • AI Boost: Joule eliminated boilerplate coding, allowing the developer to focus on business logic, such as auto-generating unique Skill IDs to avoid duplicate key errors.
  • Clean Core: Entire solution is side-by-side on SAP BTP; no modifications to the core S/4HANA system, ensuring upgrade safety.
  • Scalability: Easily extendable—can add features like Skill Gap Analysis, automatic Certification Expiry alerts, or integration with S/4HANA HR and SuccessFactors for real-time employee data sync.
  • Resilience: Built-in safeguards like UUID-based keys or ID auto-generation logic prevent data conflicts and ensure smooth multi-user usage.
  • Future-Ready: Can quickly expand to mobile apps, integrate with SAP Build Process Automation for skill approval workflows, or hook into SAP Analytics Cloud for skill heatmaps.

Conclusion
Generative AI, coupled with SAP’s robust development ecosystem, is transforming how enterprise-grade applications are built. In this journey from concept to a fully functional Finance App, SAP Build Code and Joule demonstrated how AI can eliminate repetitive tasks, accelerate delivery, and uphold clean-core principles.

What once took weeks of manual coding, data modeling, and UI design now takes minutes—without compromising quality, scalability, or integration capabilities. By combining pro-code flexibility, AI-assisted development, and SAP BTP’s enterprise foundation, teams can focus on solving real business challenges instead of wrestling with technical overhead.

This is more than a productivity boost—it’s a new paradigm for how innovation happens in the SAP landscape.

entry.title: SBPA Process Scheduler Trigger : A Step-by-Step Demo on Invoice Validation Approval
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

Welcome back to our SAP Build Process Automation series! In this third blog, we'll dive deep into one of the most crucial aspects of process automation: how to automatically start business processes using scheduler. 

What Are Scheduled Triggers?

Scheduled triggers enable you to automate the initiation of business processes at predefined intervals, eliminating the need for manual intervention or dependency on external events. By defining a time-based schedule, you can ensure that processes run exactly when you want them to, whether that’s daily, weekly, monthly, or following a custom recurrence pattern.

Key Benefits:

  • Hands-free automation – Processes start automatically without user action.
  • Enhanced efficiency – Streamlines operations by reducing delays and human error.
  • Lower manual workload – Frees up resources for higher-value activities.
  • Consistent execution – Ensures tasks run on time, every time.
  • Flexible scheduling – Supports a wide range of recurrence patterns to suit business needs.

Prerequisites

Before starting, ensure you have:

  1. Access to SAP Build Process Automation
  2. A working process (we'll use the vendor invoice validation approval process project from previous episodes)
  3. BTP Cockpit access for service key retrieval - trial cockpit

Step-by-Step Implementation 

Phase 1: Project Setup

Step 1: Create a Copy of Your Existing Project from previous blog

  1. Navigate to SAP Build Lobby
  2. Locate your existing project (e.g., "Invoice Validation Approval Process Form")
  3. Select the project by clicking on it
  4. Click "Save As" to create a copy
  5. Enter new project details: 
    1. Project Name: Invoice Validation Approval Process Scheduler 
    2. Description: A invoice validation and approval process scheduler
  6. Click "Save" to create the new project   

Step 2: Access and Prepare the Process

  1. Open the newly created project
  2. Navigate to the process section
  3. You should see:
    • Four forms
    • One process
    •  Existing form scheduler (Invoice Validation Approval Process Form)

Phase 2: Removing Existing Process and Adding Scheduled Trigger

Step 3: Remove the Existing Form Process and add the scheduled trigger

  1. Click on the existing form process (Invoice Validation Approval Process Form)
  2. Click "Remove" to delete the form
  3. You'll now see a block asking "How do you want to start your process?"
  4. Click "Add a scheduled trigger

Step 4: Create the Scheduled Trigger

  1. Click on "Scheduled Trigger"
  2. Save the process (mandatory before creating Scheduled trigger)
    • Click the Save button
  3. Configure Scheduled Trigger Details: 
    • Name: Invoice Validation Approval Process Scheduled Trigger 
    • Identifier: [Auto-generated - do not modify]
  4. Click "Create"
  5. You'll see a success message: "Scheduled trigger created successfully"  

Phase 3: Configure the Process Inputs

Step 5: Examine Scheduler Trigger Properties

  1. Click on the Scheduler trigger you just created
  2. Review Output Fields:
  • These are automatically synchronized from process inputs
  • Fields include: Vendor Name, Invoice Number, Invoice Date, Vendor Email, Invoice Amount, Due Date

Phase 4: Project Release and Deployment 

Step 6: Release the Project

  1. Save all changes
  2. Click "Release" button in the top toolbar
  3. Confirm the release when prompted
  4. Wait for successful release message

Click on the "Release" button, add the release notes (Optional) and click on the Release.

Step 7: Deploy the Project

  1. Click "Deploy" button (appears after release)
  2. Select target environment (typically "Public Environment")
  3. Confirm deployment
  4. Wait for deployment completion
  5. Note the deployment success message

Phase 5: Accessing Deployment Information 

Step 8: Navigate to Control Tower

  1. Go to SAP Build Lobby home
  2. Click on "Control Tower"
  3. Navigate to "Tenant Configuration"
  4. Click on "Environments"
  5. Select "Public Environment" (or your deployment target)

Step 9: Locate Your Deployed Project

  1. Find your project: "Invoice Validation Approval Process Scheduled Trigger"
  2. Click on the project name
  3. Navigate to "Triggers" tab
  4. Locate: "Invoice Validation Approval Process Scheduled Trigger"

Phase 6: Configure the Scheduled Trigger

Step 10: Activate the Trigger

  1. Click on the three dots under Actions
  2. Select "Activate"

Step 11: Schedule Configuration

  1. Schedule Tab Settings
    1. Date Range: August 14th, 2025 to August 25th, 2026 (1-month subscription)
    2. Time Zone: IST (Indian Standard Time)
    3. Recurrence: 5 month (monthly execution)
    4. Start Time: 9:43 MM
    5. Day Number: 1st day of every month
  2. Recurrence Options Available
    1. Minutes: Maximum 59 minutes
    2. Hours: Maximum 24 hours
    3. Days: Maximum 7 days
    4. Weeks: Maximum 35 weeks
    5. Months: Maximum 12 months

Step 12: Input Parameters

  1. Configure Input Data
    1. Switch to "Input Parameter" tab
    2. Enter the following sample data:
      1. Vendor Name
      2. Invoice Number
      3. Invoice Date
      4. Vendor Email
      5. Invoice Amount
      6. Due Date
  2. Activate Configuration
    1. Click "Activate"
    2. The trigger will be successfully updated

Phase 7: Testing and Monitoring

Step 13: Test Immediate Execution

  • After activation, you'll see new options under "Actions":
    • Disable trigger
    • Run now (for testing)
    • Edit trigger configuration
  • Click "Run now" for testing

Step 14: Monitor Process Instance

  1. Return to SAP Build Lobby
  2. Navigate to "Monitoring"
  3. Click "Process and Workflow Instances"
  4. Locate your new process instance:
    • Status: Running
    • Instance ID: [Auto-generated]
    • Started by: Scheduled Trigger

Step 15: Review Process Data

  1. Click on the process instance
  2. Review "Process Details":
    • Vendor Name: TEST VENDOR
    • Invoice Number: 1234
    • Invoice Amount: 1000
    • Vendor Email: test-vendor@test.com
    • Due Date: 2024-08-16

    3. Check process flow: Should be waiting for approval

Step 16: Review all the details and Approve the process form

Step 17: Verify Process Completion

  1. Return to "Process and Workflow Instances"
  2. Refresh the page
  3. Check your process instance:
    • Status: Completed
    • All approval messages visible
    • Complete process flow executed 

Conclusion

Scheduled triggers in SAP Build Process Automation offer a robust and flexible way to automate recurring business processes without manual intervention.

Through the vendor invoice validation approval prcess example, we see how such triggers can streamline operations, maintain consistency, and enhance efficiency by executing workflows at precise intervals. By carefully configuring schedules, input parameters, and approval steps, organizations can reduce errors, optimize resources, and scale their automation efforts.

However, success depends on thorough testing, proper security measures, and continuous monitoring to ensure reliability and performance in production environments.

entry.title: SAP Build - Get Record fetches data but properties are blank when I try to read them
entry.content:
Hey,

I'm trying to read a single data record into an app or data variable. The API works and fetches the data.

So when I output the record, I do get the object with all of the information and properties. However, when I try to read or bind one of the properties of that object to a field or variable, the result is always empty. Same thing happens when I use the Get record / Record output to bind it to a variable that was created from the same entity.

I just use the basic Get record and Set data variable/Set app variable logic.

Thanks for your help!

entry.title: SAP Build Process Automation - Automation does not complete/finish
entry.content:
Dear community,

i sat up an workflow in SAP Build Process Automation. The trigger is a pretty basic formular which i need to submit. After that, my automation starts. But here is the problem: the automation starts, executes properly but never comes to finish.

Furthermore, the output parameter of the automation is filled properly, available in the workflow but cant be used due to the fact that the automation is never stopping/completed or somehow finished. In the screenshots below and attached to this question i provided details about this issue. What can i do that the automation comes to an end?

The automation itself works in the tests without any issue and all the values are correctly parsed and mapped. It just doesn't continue as you can see in the screenshots and therefore no further steps in the workflow are executed.

Here are further screenshots additionally to the screenshots in the attachments:

entry.title: Re: SAP Build Process automation mail notification
entry.content: I think this post should be moved to the Technology Q&A part of SAP Community.

entry.title: Network error on Sap Build
entry.content:
Hello,

I have a mobile application which I made with Sap Build Web and Mobile Application( formerly known as Appgywer ). I am using an oData service on my app. It was working fine but suddenly oData service started to throw exception as "Network Error Axios Error: Network Error". 

Does anybody face same issue?

Best regards.

entry.title: Getting error while using this ODATA API to create billing document
entry.content:
Hello All,

 

I am trying to use the API  POST /BillingDocument/SAP__self.CreateFromSDDocument to create a billing document from Billing document request (BDR)   and getting error as below .please help me with the resolution.

 

"Billing of BDR 100000314 NOT SUPPORTED BECAUSE ITS SD DOCUMENT CATEGORY IS PBRQ"

entry.title: Page Mounted Event not called in published app
entry.content:
Hey,

I implemented some logic that a record collection is called when the page was mounted.

In the preview this works just fine, but when I publish the app, it seems like the event istn't even called. I placed toast after every action in the logic tab and the first toasts (after Page mounted & Page focused) aren't showing up.

Did someone have this issue before?

entry.title: Performance difference between SAP BTP Free Account and Paid Account?
entry.content:
Hi Community,

I’m currently working with an SAP BTP Free Account and I’ve noticed some performance limitations when running applications and services (for example, SAP Build Apps, CAP services, and OData calls).

Before moving to a paid account, I’d like to understand:

  • Are there any performance differences (speed, responsiveness, system resources) between Free and Paid accounts?

  • Do paid accounts get more consistent service levels (e.g., CPU/memory allocation, faster response times, higher quotas)?

  • Is there any official documentation or benchmarks comparing Free vs. Paid accounts?

I’d really appreciate insights from anyone who has tested both environments or moved from Free to Paid.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Build Code Is Slow to Load and Won’t Open Properly
entry.content:
When I try to launch Build Code, it takes a long time to load and never fully starts. It remains stuck on the screen shown in the attached image.

Occasionally, it does open, but the storyboard is blank and the Joule tab doesn’t have a place to enter prompts. Is anyone else experiencing this issue? If a solution or workaround exists, please let me know.

entry.title: SAP Document AI - item splitted to 2 pages
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

In SAP Document AI (Premium version), I run into a limitation when invoices or other documents contain line items that are split across two pages.

Instead of treating them as one item, the service always creates two separate items. I know this is a known limitation, but I’m trying to understand if there are any workarounds or configuration options that can help.

So far I’ve tried:

  • Enabling Instant Learning

  • Setting dataFeedbackCollection = true

…but it doesn’t improve the results.

  • Has anyone found a reliable way to handle split line items?

  • Are there service settings or template tricks that help?

  • Or is post-processing/merging the only practical solution at this point?

Would love to hear how others are dealing with this.

Thank you

entry.title: Facing issues while using sales order visibility scenario in sap build process automation.
entry.content:
While working on the Sales Order Management (MI03) template in SAP Build Process Automation, I customized the Determine Approver step and set up the approval flow. The process runs smoothly — forms are submitted, inbox tasks appear, and confirmation emails are triggered correctly.

To enable visibility, I followed SAP’s tutorial:
https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/spa-create-process-visibility.html

However, the visibility scenario doesn’t appear under Monitoring in SAP Build Lobby as expected.

So I deployed it and accessed it via SAP Build Work Zone, following this guide:
https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/spa-configure-workzone.html

The dashboard loads successfully, but all panels — including open instances, completed instances, cycle time, and step-level metrics — show no data available.


SAP Build Process Automation 
SAP Build 

@KarthikeyanMurthy 
@PierreCol 
@Dan_Wroblewski
